name: Heinrich Cornelius Agrippa
description: Author of De occulta philosophia, interested in the theory and practice of alchemy.

name: Masha'allah ibn Athari
description: 8th-century astrologer and astronomer, associated with De elementis and Liber de Orbe.

name: Avicebron (Solomon ibn Gabirol)
description: Author of Fons vitae, central to 12th-century cosmography.

name: Paracelsus
description: [Practitioner] Renaissance physician and alchemist, founder of iatrochemistry (Tria Prima).

name: Isaac Newton
description: [Practitioner] Physicist who spent decades studying alchemy and translating the Emerald Tablet.

name: Turba Philosophorum
description: [Text] One of the oldest Latin alchemical texts, framed as a council of philosophers.

name: John Dee
description: [Practitioner] English polymath and advisor to Elizabeth I, author of Monas Hieroglyphica.

name: Philosophical Mercury
description: [Substance] The purified, non-vulgar mercury required for the Magnum Opus.

name: Mutus Liber
description: [Text] The 'Silent Book', an alchemical treatise composed of plates without text.

name: Rosarium Philosophorum
description: [Text] 16th-century treatise illustrating the conjunction of King and Queen.

name: Zosimos of Panopolis
description: [Practitioner] 3rd-century Gnostic alchemist, author of the earliest known alchemical texts.

name: Sulphur
description: [Substance] One of the Tria Prima; represents the soul or flammable principle.

name: Cinnabar
description: [Substance] Bright red mineral (mercury sulphide), a primary source of mercury.

name: Splendor Solis
description: [Text] High-Renaissance alchemical manuscript known for its 22 elaborate miniatures.

name: Azoth
description: [Substance] Universal solvent or 'Mercury of the Philosophers', alpha and omega.

name: Salt
description: [Substance] One of the Tria Prima; represents the body or fixed principle.

name: Basil Valentine
description: [Practitioner] Legendary 15th-century monk and alchemist, author of The Twelve Keys.

name: Spirit of Wine
description: [Substance] Concentrated ethanol obtained by distillation, used as a solvent.

name: Robert Boyle
description: [Practitioner] Natural philosopher and alchemist, key figure in the transition to chemistry.

name: Nicolas Flamel
description: [Practitioner] 14th-century French scribe and legendary alchemist associated with the Stone.

name: Emerald Tablet
description: [Text] Foundational Hermetic text containing the dictum 'As above, so below'.

name: Distillation
description: [Apparatus] The separation of substances based on differences in volatility.

name: Circulation
description: [Apparatus] Continuous distillation where the distillate returns to the base.

name: Philosophical Egg
description: [Allegory] The sealed vessel in which the alchemical transformation occurs.

name: Retort
description: [Apparatus] A glass vessel with a long, downward-pointing neck used for distillation.

name: Athanor
description: [Apparatus] The furnace used by alchemists to maintain a constant heat.

name: Putrefaction
description: [Apparatus] The breakdown of organic or alchemical matter, often the first stage.

name: Fermentation
description: [Apparatus] The stage where the Stone is infused with vitality and power.

name: Projection
description: [Apparatus] The final act of using the Stone to transmute base metals into gold.

name: Vitriol
description: [Substance] Sulphuric acid, associated with the acronym VITRIOL (Visita Interiora Terrae...).

name: Multiplication
description: [Apparatus] Increasing the quantity and quality of the Philosopher's Stone.

name: Sublimation
description: [Apparatus] The transition of a substance from solid to gas phase directly.

name: George Ripley
description: [Practitioner] English alchemist and canon, author of The Compound of Alchymy.

name: Twelve Keys of Basil Valentine
description: [Text] Influential treatise describing the steps of the Great Work.

name: Musaeum Hermeticum
description: [Text] 17th-century collection of Hermetic and alchemical works.

name: Albertus Magnus
description: [Practitioner] Medieval scholar and theologian with significant alchemical attributions.

name: Hermes Trismegistus
description: [Practitioner] Legendary founder of Hermeticism and alchemy, associated with the Emerald Tablet.

name: Michael Maier
description: [Practitioner] German alchemist and physician to Rudolf II, author of Atalanta Fugiens.

name: Aurora Consurgens
description: [Text] 15th-century manuscript attributed to Thomas Aquinas, rich in allegories.

name: Roger Bacon
description: [Practitioner] English philosopher and Franciscan friar, interested in experimental science and alchemy.

name: Summa Perfectionis
description: [Text] Influential Latin alchemical work likely written by Paul of Taranto.

name: Petrus Bonus
description: [Practitioner] 14th-century alchemist, author of the Margarita Pretiosa Novella.

name: Robert Fludd
description: [Practitioner] English physician and alchemist, noted for his encyclopedic Hermetic works.

name: Frances Yates
description: [Practitioner] Historian known for her work on the Hermetic tradition and the 'Rosicrucian Enlightenment'.

name: Michael Sendivogius
description: [Practitioner] Polish alchemist and diplomat, developer of the 'nitric' theory of life.

name: Oswald Croll
description: [Practitioner] Paracelsian physician and chemist, author of Basilica Chymica.

name: Jean D'Espagnet
description: [Practitioner] French counselor and alchemist, author of Arcanum Hermeticae Philosophiae.

name: Eirenaeus Philalethes
description: [Practitioner] Pseudonym for an influential 17th-century alchemist, likely George Starkey.

name: Theatrum Chemicum
description: [Text] Massive 17th-century compendium of alchemical writings.

name: Jabir ibn Hayyan
description: [Practitioner] 8th-century Persian polymath, credit for the sulphur-mercury theory.

name: Calcination
description: [Apparatus] The process of heating a substance to high temperatures to oxidize it.

name: Raymond Lull
description: [Practitioner] Major figure in medieval logic and alchemy (though much is pseudo-Lullian).

name: Tria Prima
description: [Allegory] The three principles: Salt, Sulphur, and Mercury.

name: Thomas Vaughan
description: [Practitioner] Welsh alchemist and priest, wrote under the pseudonym Eugenius Philalethes.

name: Mary the Jewess
description: [Practitioner] Early alchemist (1st-3rd century) credited with inventing the bain-marie.

name: George Starkey
description: [Practitioner] Colonial American alchemist and physician, tutor to Robert Boyle.

name: Theatrum Chemicum Britannicum
description: [Text] Elias Ashmole's collection of English alchemical poetry.

name: Atalanta Fugiens
description: [Text] Emblem book by Michael Maier combining alchemy, music, and myth.

name: Peacock's Tail
description: [Allegory] The display of many colors during the alchemical process.

name: Green Lion
description: [Allegory] Allegory for a corrosive acid or the initial raw state of mercury.

name: Andreas Libavius
description: [Practitioner] German physician and chemist, author of Alchymia.

name: Heinrich Khunrath
description: [Practitioner] German physician and Paracelsian alchemist, author of Amphitheatrum Sapientiae Eternae.

name: Arthur Dee
description: [Practitioner] Son of John Dee, alchemist and physician to Czar Michael I.

name: Secretum Secretorum
description: [Text] The 'Secret of Secrets', a medieval mirror for princes with alchemical sections.

name: Natural Magic
description: The practice of using hidden powers within nature, as discussed by Agrippa.

name: Psychology and Alchemy
description: [Text] C.G. Jung's foundational work on alchemical symbolism.

name: Crucible
description: [Apparatus] Heat-resistant container used for melting metals.

name: Alchymia
description: [Text] Andreas Libavius's systematization of chemical knowledge.

name: Hyle
description: The 'ultimate superior things' or prime matter in medieval cosmography and alchemy.

name: Alembic
description: [Apparatus] A tool for distillation, consisting of two vessels and a tube.

name: Sal Ammoniac
description: [Substance] Ammonium chloride, essential for many alchemical distillations.

name: Triumphal Chariot of Antimony
description: [Text] Treatise by Basil Valentine on the medicinal use of antimony.

name: Antimony
description: [Substance] Mineral often called the 'Grey Wolf' used in the purification of gold.

name: Ouroboros
description: [Allegory] Symbol of a serpent eating its own tail, representing cyclical nature.

name: Solve et Coagula
description: [Allegory] Alchemical maxim meaning 'Dissolve and Coagulate'.

name: Coagulation
description: [Apparatus] The process of thickening or solidifying a liquid.

name: Cucurbit
description: [Apparatus] The lower part of a still, often shaped like a gourd.

name: Nigredo
description: [Allegory] The 'Blackening' stage, representing putrefaction and death.

name: Arnald of Villanova
description: [Practitioner] 13th-century physician and alchemist, attributed with many works on the Stone.

name: Basilica Chymica
description: [Text] Oswald Croll's pharmaceutical and alchemical textbook.

name: Homunculus
description: [Allegory] The 'little man' created through alchemical or magical means.

name: Aqua Regia
description: [Substance] A mixture of nitric and hydrochloric acids capable of dissolving gold.

name: C.G. Jung
description: [Practitioner] Psychologist who analyzed alchemical symbolism and its relation to the psyche.

name: The Phoenix
description: [Allegory] Symbol of rebirth and the attainment of the Red Stone.

name: The Pelican
description: [Allegory] Symbol of self-sacrifice and nourishment of the work.

name: Didier Kahn
description: [Practitioner] Modern scholar focusing on Paracelsianism in early modern France.

name: Rubedo
description: [Allegory] The 'Reddening' stage, representing the final goal.

name: Albedo
description: [Allegory] The 'Whitening' stage, representing purification.

name: Margarita Pretiosa Novella
description: [Text] The 'New Precious Pearl' by Petrus Bonus.

name: John Dastin
description: [Practitioner] English alchemist and correspondent with Pope John XXII.

name: Arsenic
description: [Substance] Potent poison used as a whitening agent in alchemical metallurgy.

name: Chemical Wedding
description: [Allegory] The union of opposites, often depicted as a royal marriage.

name: Red King
description: [Allegory] Represents the fixed principle or the completion of the Rubedo stage.

name: White Queen
description: [Allegory] Represents the volatile principle or the Albedo stage.

name: Mircea Eliade
description: [Practitioner] Historian of religion who explored the mythic dimensions of metallurgy and alchemy.

name: Lawrence Principe
description: [Practitioner] Modern historian of science focusing on the reality of alchemical practice.

name: William Newman
description: [Practitioner] Modern historian of science known for work on George Starkey and deck-making.

name: Monas Hieroglyphica
description: [Text] Symbolic work by John Dee explaining a single hieroglyphic sign.

name: Rebis
description: [Allegory] The 'Two-Thing', a hermaphroditic figure representing the end of the work.

name: Magnum Opus
description: [Allegory] The 'Great Work' of creating the Philosopher's Stone.

name: Lapis Philosophorum
description: [Substance] The Philosopher's Stone, the goal of the Great Work.

name: Stockholm Papyrus
description: [Text] Companion to the Leyden Papyrus, focused on dyeing and gemstones.

name: Ostanes
description: [Practitioner] Legendary Persian magus and alchemist mentioned by Pliny.

name: Bolos of Mendes
description: [Practitioner] Greek alchemist (c. 200 BC), author of Physika kai Mystika.

name: Bernard Trevisan
description: [Practitioner] 15th-century Italian alchemist dedicated to the search for the Stone.

name: Bruce Moran
description: [Practitioner] Modern scholar focusing on the patronage systems of alchemists.

name: Tara Nummedal
description: [Practitioner] Modern historian focusing on the social and legal aspects of alchemy.

name: Joachim Telle
description: [Practitioner] Renowned German scholar of early modern alchemical literature.

name: Herbert Silberer
description: [Practitioner] Psychoanalyst who linked alchemical symbolism with psychic phenomena.

name: Pamela Smith
description: [Practitioner] Modern historian focusing on the material culture of alchemy and science.

name: Sand Bath
description: [Apparatus] A method of heating a vessel using hot sand for even temperatures.

name: Mortar and Pestle
description: [Apparatus] Basic tools used for grinding and mixing solid materials.

name: Ash Bath
description: [Apparatus] Similar to a sand bath, but using ashes for gentler heat.

name: Leyden Papyrus X
description: [Text] Ancient Egyptian recipe book for metallurgical imitations.

name: Ripley Scroll
description: [Text] Large illustrated scroll depicting the alchemical process according to George Ripley.

name: Mary Anne Atwood
description: [Practitioner] 19th-century author of A Suggestive Inquiry into the Hermetic Mystery.

name: Johann Thölde
description: [Practitioner] Salt-maker and publisher of the works of Basil Valentine.

name: Citrinitas
description: [Allegory] The 'Yellowing' stage, representing awakening.

name: A Suggestive Inquiry
description: [Text] Mary Anne Atwood's 19th-century work on the psychological mystery of alchemy.

name: Fons Vitae
description: [Text] The 'Fountain of Life', significant Neoplatonic-alchemical influence.

name: Chrysopoeia of Cleopatra
description: [Text] Early Greek alchemical papyrus focused on the production of gold.

name: Pelikan
description: [Apparatus] A circulatory distillation vessel with two side arms.

name: Fixation of the Volatile
description: [Allegory] The process of making a volatile substance stable.

name: Agathodaemon
description: [Practitioner] Early alchemist often associated with the discovery of arsenic.
